aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Aviat A-1 in Rolla, North Dakota
The accident occurred in Rolla, North Dakota.
The accident occurred on August 28, 2012, at 19:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was an AVIAT INC A-1.
The defining event was loss of engine power (total).
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN12LA587.
The aircraft registration was N49363.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 2 occupants in the aircraft.
No injuries occurred in the accident.
The pilot self-fueled the airplane with 40 gallons of fuel before the cross-country flight.
The engine stopped producing power about 10 miles from the destination airport.
The pilot made a forced landing to a field.
The aircraft flipped over during the forced landing.
A postaccident examination revealed the right wing's fuel cap was missing.
The missing fuel cap could not be located.
The top of the wing area around the fuel cap was stained blue.
The blue staining extended back toward the trailing edge.
The blue staining was consistent with fuel venting overboard.
The left wing fuel tank was empty of fuel.
Less than 1 cup of fuel was drained from the right wing fuel tank.
No mechanical malfunctions were noted with the airplane.
No anomalies were noted with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's failure to secure the right wing's fuel cap before the flight.
The probable cause included the pilot's failure to properly manage the available fuel supply during the flight.
The failure to secure the fuel cap and manage fuel resulted in a loss of engine power due to fuel exhaustion.
The findings included issues with aircraft fuel fluid management.
The findings included personnel issues related to decision making/judgment by the pilot.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Rolla, North Dakota

## Date & Time: 
August 28, 2012, 19:00 Local

## Aircraft:
AVIAT INC A-1

## Defining Event:
Loss of engine power (total)

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN12LA587

## Registration:
N49363

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

The pilot stated that he self-fueled the airplane with 40 gallons of fuel before the cross-country flight. About 10 miles from his destination airport, the engine stopped producing power. The pilot made a forced landing to a field and flipped over. A postaccident examination of the airplane revealed the right wing's fuel cap was missing and could not be located. The top of the wing area around the fuel cap and back toward the trailing edge was stained blue, which was consistent with fuel venting overboard. Examination of the left wing fuel tank revealed it was empty of fuel and less than 1 cup of fuel was drained from the right wing fuel tank. No mechanical malfunctions or anomalies were noted with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be: The pilot's failure to secure the right wing's fuel cap before the flight and to properly manage the available fuel supply during the flight, which resulted in a loss of engine power due to fuel exhaustion.

## Findings

| | |
|-|-|
| Aircraft | Fuel - Fluid management |
| Personnel issues | Decision making/judgment - Pilot |

---
